input_text.Prompt:
Walmart Canada has taken down its online photo processing store following a "potential compromise of customer credit card data."

The chain said it was recently informed of the potential breach of its Photocentre website.

"We immediately launched an investigation and will be contacting customers who may be impacted," Walmart said. "At this time, we have no reason to believe that Walmart.ca, Walmart.com or in-store transactions are affected. "

The chain has immediately suspended the photo website and all mobile applications pending an investigation. The chains recommends that anyone concerned by the breach should monitor card transactions closely, and immediately alert the financial institution involved about any unauthorized charges.

The Globe and Mail, citing an unnamed source, says as many as 60,000 people could be impacted.

Generate a summary:
input_text.Response A: Walmart Canada has taken down its online photo processing store following a "potential compromise of customer credit card data".  The chain recommends that anyone concerned by the breach should monitor card transactions closely, and immediately alert the financial institution involved about any unauthorized charges.
input_text.Response B:
Walmart Canada has removed its online photo processing store following a "potential compromise of customer credit card data." The retailer said it was recently informed of the potential breach of its Photocentre website. "We immediately launched an investigation and will be contacting customers who may be impacted," Walmart said. "At this time, we have no reason to believe that Walmart.ca, Walmart.com or in-store transactions are affected." The chain has immediately suspended the photo website and all mobile applications pending an investigation. The chain recommends that anyone concerned by the breach should monitor card transactions closely, and immediately alert the financial institution involved about any unauthorized charges.

In a statement, Walmart Canada said the potential breach only affected its online photo store. "We recently became aware of a potential compromise of customer credit card data in connection with our online photo processing service," the statement said. "We immediately launched an investigation and will be contacting customers who may be impacted. We have no reason to believe that Walmart.ca, Walmart.com or in-store transactions are affected."

The company has suspended the photo website and all mobile applications pending an investigation.

This is the second data breach involving a Canadian retailer this year. In March, Hudson's Bay Co. said that its online and in-store systems were potentially compromised, which could affect up to one million customers.

In a statement, Walmart Canada said it will not be providing any additional details about the breach to protect the integrity of the investigation.

The Globe and Mail, citing an unnamed source, says as many as 60,000 people could be impacted.

Walmart Canada has removed its online photo processing store following a "potential compromise of customer credit card data." The retailer said it was recently informed of the potential breach of its Photocentre website. "We immediately launched an investigation and will be contacting customers who may be impacted," Walmart said. "At this time, we have no reason to believe that Walmart.ca, Walmart.com or in-store transactions are affected." The chain has immediately suspended the photo website and all mobile applications pending an investigation. The chains recommends that anyone concerned by the breach should monitor card transactions closely, and immediately alert the financial institution involved about any unauthorized charges.
